0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Duodenal ulcer disease, Active: treatment, 1 gram ORALLY 4 times daily OR 2 grams twice daily for 4 to 8 weeks
  • Duodenal ulcer disease, Maintenance: 1 grams ORALLY twice daily
  • Gastric ulcer: maintenance, 1 grams ORALLY twice daily
  • Stress ulcer; Prophylaxis: 1 gram NG or ORALLY every 6 hours

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• safety and efficacy in pediatric patients not established
  • Duodenal ulcer disease, Active: treatment, 40 to 80 mg/kg/day ORALLY divided every 6 hours OR 0.5 to 1 gram 4 times daily
  • Duodenal ulcer disease, Maintenance: (1 to 10 y) 1 gram ORALLY at bedtime
  • Gastric ulcer: treatment, 40 to 80 mg/kg/day ORALLY divided every 6 hours OR 0.5-1 gram 4 times daily
  • Stress ulcer; Prophylaxis: infant, 40 mg/kg/day NG or ORALLY in 4 divided doses
  • Stress ulcer; Prophylaxis: children, 40 to 80 mg/kg/day NG or ORALLY in 4 divided doses; maximum 4 g/day

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: hypersensitivity to sucralfate or any of its excipients

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• chronic renal failure and dialysis patients; increased risk of aluminum accumulation and toxicity (eg, aluminum osteodystrophy, osteomalacia, and encephalopathy)
  • conditions that may impair swallowing, including recent or prolonged intubation, tracheostomy, prior aspiration, dysphagia, diminished oropharyngeal coordination or motility, or conditions that alter gag and cough reflexes; tablet aspiration accompanied by respiratory complications has been reported (tablet)
  • diabetic patients; hyperglycemia has been reported; monitoring recommended; dose adjustments may be required (suspension)

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
Gastrointestinal:Constipation (2%)
Serious
  • Endocrine metabolic:Hyperglycemia, In diabetic patients
  • Gastrointestinal:Bezoar
  • Other:Aluminum toxicity, In patients with chronic renal failure or on dialysis

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Oral-Local: Exact mechanism of action is not known; however, sucralfate is thought to form an ulcer-adherent complex with proteinaceous exudate, such as albumin and fibrinogen, at the ulcer site, protecting it against further acid attack . To a lesser extent, sucralfate forms a viscous, adhesive barrier on the surface of intact mucosa of the stomach and duodenum . Sucralfate also inhibits pepsin activity and has been found to bind bile salts in vitro. Recent information suggests that sucralfate may increase the production of prostaglandin E 2 and gastric mucus .

0.title: Absorption
0.mono: Food effect: interferes, administer on an empty stomach

3.title: Excretion
3.mono: Oral-Local: Fecal: Primarily; Renal: small amounts

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • give on empty stomach
  • antacids should not be taken within one-half hour before or after administration
  • do not take cimetidine, ciprofloxacin, digoxin, norfloxacin, ofloxacin, and ranitidine within 2 h before administration

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• signs and symptoms or endoscopic improvement is indicative of efficacy
  • blood glucose levels in diabetic patients
  • renal function in elderly patients

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This drug may cause constipation, bezoar formation, and aluminum toxicity.
  • Advise patient to take drug on empty stomach.
  • Patient should not take antacids 30 min before or after taking this drug.
  • Tell patient to avoid taking cimetidine, ciprofloxacin, digoxin, norfloxacin, ofloxacin, and ranitidine 2 h before or after taking sucralfate.
